nodes.bodyText: I would expect you'd want to [END functions_ocr_process] here and start it just before accept().
Done.
This method seems a bit tiny and pointless as a teaching example - it really only has a single significant line.  I wonder if you might want to do this a bit differently?

I was copying the Node example.
(Though I agree this might be worth refactoring - detectText is a borderline "God method", so maybe we should move the Pub/Sub publishing code to this method instead?)
Let's keep things simple and only ask the user to follow one method.
Why do we do this?
Just because you use a try w/ resources doesn't mean you need to ever catch anything.

The Base BackgroundFunction type in the Functions Framework can only throw subclasses of RuntimeException, which these are not.
(IntelliJ requires the exception to be addressed in a catch block - even if that block merely ignores the error.)

https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s6.2-caught-exceptions
Also see Effective Java v3 Exceptions

Item 69: Use exceptions only for exceptional conditions
Item 70: Use checked exceptions for recoverable conditions and runtime exceptions for programming errors
Item 71: Avoid unnecessary use of checked exceptions
Item 72: Favor the use of standard exceptions
Item 73: Throw exceptions appropriate to the abstraction
Item 74: Document all exceptions thrown by each method
Item 77: Don’t ignore exceptions
What if you just say throws IOException ?

Ah - so (some of) these seem more like "checked" exceptions.
In that case, maybe it would be better to log them and exit the function?

Spoke with lesv@ about this - initial thoughts are that the best case would be to add a FunctionException (ala  ServerletException) to the Functions framework interface for handling these type of things.  Would you mind opening an issue for this?
A reasonable workaround until that is added is log (with Logger.error) in the meantime.
Please log over RuntimeException everywhere.
Why don't you throw something here?
Switched to RuntimeException.
Why?
Ditto.
Is this a success?

Added a log statement.
I'm somewhat reluctant to throw an exception here, as this could be caused by bad user input (as opposed to programmer error.)
Is this a success?
Added a log statement. (See above comment for more info.)
Why?
See comment above.
Why?
@kurtisvg has a preference for getters/setters - but I can drop these if you'd prefer.
Your not using them outside your class, so I'd prefer dropping them, but feel free to ask kurtis about my comment.
Will do. Also, these are used outside the class (e.g. here)
Spoke with Les - we should use getters/setter from outside of the class (like where you linked) but make sure to use the internal reference (like in fromPubSubData).
Since it's your class, you can access directly.  No reason to use the accessors.
Done.
Why?
Ditto.
Why?
Ditto.
This is still very wrong.

Compiler error: Overridden method accept(...) does not throw IOException
(This would have to be fixed in the Functions Framework itself. If you'd like, I can file an issue.)
Is there a reason why we are splitting this class into two functions? Seems like it makes it harder to copy/paste

The existing samples do that. (@lesv had similar feedback)
If you'd like, I can move the Pub/Sub publishing code to functions_ocr_process since detectText is quite long.
Done.
This isn't imported from anywhere? Is it supposed to be com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage?
Any reason not to make this a com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage instead of byte[]?

There's also a PubSubMessage (capitalized s) POJO here, that's necessary for deserializing incoming Pub/Sub events.
(I tried deserializing into the com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage type, but the default Gson deserializer couldn't handle it. Longer-term, we should probably write a custom deserializer for this class within the Pub/Sub client library.)
#fyi @chingor13
Don't need to throw unchecked exceptions
Per your comment below, I moved this into the constructor.
com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage looks like it has a getData that returns a String. Can you use that instead of decoding?
See conversation above - it doesn't (yet) work with Cloud Functions' event de-serialization logic.

Moved validation into the constructor - PTAL?
(I opted to keep the fromJson() call here, as I'm assuming that will call the constructor which will in turn handle the validation - LMK if I should replace that with parseString().)
Any reason not to use com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage over byte? seems like a weird place to split up the helper functions.
See other comments about this not working with Gson
Any reason not to inline these three variables?
Done.

Why are we checking if response == null? Does the client actually return that as a result?
Can we add a comment inside function explaining why it's returning?
This was a defensive programming reflex - removed. 🙂
Should use either a setter (or constructor) to set these fields.
Done.

Please use java.time for this instead.  You can use something like Instance.now().minus(5, MINUTES)
Additionally, this check doesn't actually verify it worked when run in parallel (as we do with our unit tests).

Replaced this with a UUID'd filename + existence check. 🙂
(The downside is that this also required implementing teardown code.)
(please fix everywhere else)
Done.
nit: Did you mean to downgrade this?

nodes.bodyText: We shouldn't rewrap errors like this - the visionResponse isn't an IOException.
Added a separate logging statement instead - PTAL?
